awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project - Center for Engineering and Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in STEM and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Benedict College seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines.  The objectives and strategies of the Center for Engineering and Science are consistent with Benedict College's goal of increasing the number of well-prepared STEM graduates who enter in the workforce as engineers, teachers, or pursue STEM graduate education and research careers.

The objectives of the project are to: 1) increase retention of STEM freshmen students; 2) increase the five-year graduation rate of STEM majors; and 3) increase the number of engineering and science majors who gain admission and matriculate to graduate school. The project strategies supporting these objectives are evidence-based and will be monitored and evaluated for effectiveness. This evaluation will help to decide which activities will be sustained by Benedict College and will be disseminated as best practices for peer institutions.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of the Project include the following:

1. Establishment of the Center for Engineering and Science.

2. Establishment of the Center for Advanced Materials 

3. Establishment of the Advanced Computing Lab

4. Establishment of the Office of Veteran Student Support

5. Implemented HBCU-UP Pre-Freshman Bridge Academy, allowing incoming students to take courses in mathematics, biology, and English writing (2015-2019, over 60 students)

6. Establishment of STEM Peer Tutorial Center: recruited and paid upper-classmen to serve as peer tutors in mathematics and science courses (2015-2019). This program is now institutionalized as the Students Success Center.

7. Increased access to Computer-Assisted Support for Mathematics by providing Matlab and Simulink licenses from Mathworks during 2015-2019.

8. Established the Lamar Building Computer lab for engineering students and faculty.

9. Implemented Summer Program for Transition from Freshman to Sophomore status (2015-2017, over 30 students). We couldn't continue this activity due to merging two semester-long summer classes into one online summer semester.

10. Established an online Research Principles and Ethics Course (SCI 331 Ethics in Science)

11. Established a Graduate School Test Preparation course (STEM 328 Career Entrance Exams Prep)

12. Graduate school application support for students (application fees were paid for 20 students)

13.  Established HBCU-UP Scholar Program (100 students)

14.  Support for students and faculty for an 8-week on-campus summer research experience (average 5-6 students and 5-6 faculty per year for 2014-2022).

15.  Attendance at professional meetings: 4-5 students per year were supported to attend the National Society of Black Engineers conference, 2014-2019. Many students were able to secure internships and employment offers at this conference.

16. ABET Accreditation: The Dean of the School of STEM and the Environmental Engineering faculty hired a consultant to provide training and guidance throughout the accreditation process. The HBCU-UP Implementation project supported Computer Science and Environmental Engineering faculty to receive ABET workshop on fundamentals of program assessment during 2015-2019. The ABET coordinator for the program, was supported with a stipend during the Summer of 2019 to complete the required Readiness Review (pre-cursor to the Self Study Report for accreditation). This NSF funding also covered ABET application and site visit fees. As a result, the Environmental Engineering program received its initial accreditation in 2022 with a retrospective effect from 2018.

Benedict College?s Environmental Engineering program receives accreditation | Benedict College | Columbia, South Carolina

17. The HBCU-UP Implementation Project has changed the faculty student research culture at the institute. One new faculty hired from this grant has earned tenure and received multiple NIH funding.

18. The African-American undergraduates gained scientific knowledge and research skills required to succeed as engineers and scientists.

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2022
Modified by: Samir S Raychoudhury
